newsitem.title: GERMANY: Key German sugar area expects higher beet yield.
newsitem.headline: Key German sugar area expects higher beet yield.

text.p: Key northern German sugar producer Zuckerverbund Nord AG (ZVN) said beet yields should be higher than last year due to favourable weather.
"We assume the yield will be at least 50 tonnes per hectare or exceed it," a ZVN official said on Tuesday.
Average yields in Lower Saxony, where ZVN operates, were 48.4 tonnes last year, when the average across Germany was 50.7 tonnes.
Heavy rains in July, which hampered Germany's barley harvest and caused some damage to other crops, helped the beet crop store water and gain weight.
Leaf structures and weights in the ZVN growing regions were healthy and well developed and excessive moisture was a problem only on clay soils.
National sugar industry association WVZ said it had not revised a July 9 prediction of high yields from this year's beet crop, grown on 508,687 hectares.
Detailed fortnightly beet tests will be released from Monday, August 4.
